Award.AwardTitle: Metal Diborides: Investigating the Structure, Processing, and Properties of a New Class of Two-Dimensional Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Metal diborides are a class of ceramic materials with the chemical composition MB2, where M can be many different metals. They have a common structure of stacked sheets of boron separated by layers of metal atoms. Examples of the diverse, outstanding properties of these materials include superconductivity in magnesium diboride and resistance to extremely high temperatures in titanium diboride and zirconium diboride. Metal diborides also find application in ballistic armor and heat shields for spacecraft. However, conventional methods of preparing metal diborides result in thick, brittle materials that do not take advantage of the flexible, two-dimensional (2D) nature of their constituent boron sheets. The PIs recently developed a method to directly generate substantial amounts of 2D metal diborides composed of single- to few-layer atomically thin sheets. This project is focused on studying in detail the structure, properties, processing, and performance of this new class of 2D ceramics. Few-layer metal diborides suspended across porous surfaces or incorporated into polymers are tested for their improved mechanical properties. Thin films of the 2D metal diborides are investigated for their potential as lightweight and flexible superconductors. Overall, these studies aim to exploit the exceptional properties of the metal diborides in applications not possible using conventional materials processing techniques and to improve their performance in their conventional areas of use. The educational goals of this project are the training of graduate and undergraduate students in advanced materials research, incorporation of research results into the PIs' interdisciplinary courses for graduate and undergraduate students, and outreach to students and families in the general public through open house science events and at-home virtual science kits.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project is focused on understanding in detail the structure and properties of 2D sheets of metal diborides prepared using solution-phase processing and micromechanical cleavage techniques. The structure and composition of these 2D materials are studied down to the atomic scale by aberration corrected transmission electron microscopy, scanning tunneling microscopy, electron energy loss spectroscopy, and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy. Mechanical measurements across different length scales, starting from individual microscopic sheets of 2D metal diborides to macroscopic polymer composites reinforced by 2D metal diborides, are being studied using atomic force microscopy and tensile testing equipment. Solution-processed, flexible thin films of the 2D metal diboride MgB2 are being investigated for their potential superconducting behavior. This research project is thus providing new fundamental knowledge of the electronic and mechanical properties of the metal diborides once they are only a few atomic layers thick. The improved understanding of the properties and processing of 2D metal diboride ceramics is facilitating their integration into stretchable and flexible forms unavailable to their conventional bulk counterparts, and yielding new application areas for these compounds in structurally reinforced polymer composites and bendable superconductors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The metal diborides are a family of materials with the general chemical formula MB2 that consist of layers of metal atoms sandwiched between layers of boron atoms arranged in a honeycomb lattice. In their macroscopic form, the metal diborides possess remarkable properties, including extremely high melting temperatures, exceptional mechanical strength and hardness, and high-temperature superconductivity. This project was focused on developing methods to produce extremely thin sheets of the metal diborides and investigating their properties and potential applications. The nanosheet form will enable new applications and contexts for metal diborides that are not feasible in their bulk forms.

 

Ultrathin sheets of eight different metal diboride compositions were prepared using liquid-phase exfoliation in a variety of different solvents and aqueous surfactant solutions. This process exposes metal diboride powders to ultrasonic forces in suitable solvents which enables their exfoliation into thin sheets. Characterization of the nanosheets using atomic force microscopy and transmission electron microscopy demonstrated that sheets down to three nanometers in thickness and lateral dimensions ranging from 50 nm to several microns could be produced. These measurements further showed that the nanosheets retained the honeycomb structure of the macroscopic metal diborides and their chemical composition.

 

To better understand the conditions necessary to produce metal diboride nanosheets, two representative compositions, MgB2 and CrB2, were exfoliated in an extensive collection of organic solvents to determine their Hansen solubility parameters. Both metal diboride compositions exhibited noticeably higher polar and hydrogen-bonding parameters than more well-studied liquid-phase exfoliated nanomaterials such as graphene and molybdenum disulfide, suggesting a greater preference for more polar solvents. The Hansen solubility parameters were harnessed to identify combinations of two solvents that offered improved metal diboride nanosheets with increased concentrations and stabilities. The ability to tailor combinations of solvents and metal diborides with optimal characteristics is critical for future industrial applications of these materials.

 

Leveraging the scalability of the liquid-phase exfoliation process and knowledge of the affinity for particular solvents, the metal diboride nanosheets were incorporated as fillers into different composite forms. Integration of chromium diboride nanosheets into the polymer polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) led to significant increases in the composite material?s strength and stiffness with only small increases in mass. Methods to incorporate the metal diborides into 3D-printed structures were also developed. These methods enabled the nanosheets to serve as fillers in complex 3D structures and were successfully combined with ceramic structures with high-temperature stability.

 

The metal diborides were further studied to investigate their catalytic activity and interactions with biological systems. These experiments revealed that hafnium diboride nanosheets coated with biocompatible polymers displayed notable peroxidase activity, significantly higher than many other solution-processed nanoscale materials. The hafnium diboride preparations were further exposed to cultures of bacteria and mammalian cells to determine their effect on cell viability. These studies demonstrated that the hafnium diboride nanosheets could eradicate both Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria at concentrations as low as 10 ?g/mL, killing >99.999% of the bacterial cells. This concentration is far lower than the amounts needed to kill bacteria for other commonly used antibacterial nanosheets, such as graphene oxide and molybdenum disulfide. In contrast, biocompatibility measurements of mammalian cells exposed to the same concentration of hafnium diboride nanosheets showed that greater than 90% cell viability.

 

Overall, this project developed efficient methods to produce 2D metal diborides and led to a detailed understanding of the conditions necessary to generate highly concentrated and stable dispersions of metal diboride nanosheets. These methods can be used for future industrialization of ultrathin metal diborides and inform strategies to exfoliate materials with similar layered structures. The ability of the metal diboride nanosheets to serve as filler materials in nanocomposites with improved strength and stiffness suggests that they can be applied in the future to make plastics that are both strong and light and in 3D-printed ceramics with enhanced properties. The remarkable antibacterial activity of the hafnium diboride nanosheets indicates that these materials could have broader impact in combatting the spread of drug-resistant bacteria in contexts such as wound dressings and antibacterial surfaces.

 

The broader outcomes of this project were the training of multiple graduate students at the PhD and MS levels, and multiple undergraduate student researchers in advanced materials research techniques. These students completed thesis projects, contributed to presentations, posters, journal articles, and patents. The PhD students have joined the workforce in industry as R&D scientists, and the completed BS students are pursuing PhD programs. Activities and outreach for children in the general public were also developed and implemented both online and in hands-on demonstrations throughout this project.
